text: Patient: I got to talk to the heart doctor now because he has me on the aspirin and the… Family Member: Unless you think… Patient: The tush doctor told me no aspirin. text: Patient: Oh, tailgate with my college football friends. It was homecoming. Doctor: Okay, you’re making me work hard Mr. S____. You know what we have to do? We have to repeat your scans anyways because it’s time. You’re last one was July. Patient: My what scan? Doctor: Your CAT scan/bone scan just to see what’s going on. I’m not sure that the leg’s anything. You know, sometimes it’s a red herring like hey, I’ve been driving and I was partying and then it kind of hurt. We’re always perpetually paranoid about clots. You know that. Any type of blood clot. But I don’t think you have that because normally it shows up in our lower legs and our calves and your calves are as skinny as they come so and they don’t hurt and they’re not swollen so we’ll leave it there. But that leg, you know, we always have to fuss about because we know your bone scan can change at any time. I know we finished chemo but it might be time to figure out what else is happening. You look great so I’m thrilled about that but I also don’t want to just rely on the PSA and whatever to see what’s happening so CAT scan, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Patient: Same thing I had before. Doctor: And bone scan, same thing. Now, let’s fast forward so we don’t freak out that if it’s worse, and you know my definition of worse is not the stuff went away that’s back, it’s just do I see more things or black spots on your bone scan. Your bone scan doesn’t changed much as you know. It kind of looks perpetually icky based on your original so you haven’t changed this whole time. I’m looking to see if there’s new spots in the leg or anywhere else. Now that I know you have pain and discomfort there, I of course look there to make sure there is nothing new there. Patient: Well, this only started when I… Doctor: Yeah, so you know… Patient: I’ve been having pain in my back but I had that. That’s when my back was hurting then right after that it was found out that I the cancer and they went ahead so. Doctor: Right, yeah, so we’ll just follow to make sure it’s nothing new, anything new that pops up and of course you’re getting the CAT scan because I want to make sure there’s nothing new in the liver or the lungs or anything as well. I’m not expecting it to but we have to check. Now, if your PSA is just, you know, creeping up, which it kind of is, I know. Patient: It went up. Doctor: Yeah, it did, it did. You’re actually at, wait, you were…. Patient: I was at 19.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And in, in having an immune drug on board seems to make that whole thing work better. Um, I don’t have the answer for this vaccine radium combination, whether it’s going to do anything. But that’s, that’s the idea behind it is let’s bring these two things together. Uh, so, uh, again, if I had to say which one has the best chance of working for you right now is probably going to be a second hormone treatment. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and I think given where you are with the disease in the bone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I, I would probably lean towards something that I’d feel like we have a better chance of, of success. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, even though some of these things sound cool, I don’t really have a good sense of, you know. So I’d, I’d like to choose either a trial with a hormone drug or just do the hormone drug, uh, as the next step. Patient: Are you satisfied with that we go to? Family Member: Um hum. Patient: I am if you are too?. Family Member: Do you want to do the one, have him go to that one that has, uh, Xtandi and the other one that-? Doctor: The Zytiga or the, no, you mean the trial?

text: Patient: Huh. Doctor: I still get my blood test. Patient: Oh okay you still uh? How many times? Doctor: Once a year now. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So in twenty years it’s probably gonna be time for me to stop, but we check your blood, we’ll be checking blood for a long time.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Not, not that there was anything different before or after. So, uh, the two drugs, about sixty plus percent of men respond overall. So that’s what I said. About two-thirds of the guys respond, and then one-third seems to have a long response, and one-third has a shorter response, and one-third don’t. Uh, in terms of how to pick which one of those two. Uh, for a while, I, I was picking Zytiga instead of Xtandi. Zytiga, the one complication with Zytiga, is you have to take a small dose of prednisone with it, uh, to kind of counterbalance how Zytiga works. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the one reason we would do that is because we had some trials, uh, that were after Zytiga. But the other reason was a tendency of less fatigue with the Zytiga than the Xtandi, in my experience. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Both drugs can cause fatigue. But it seems to be more common and often a little bit worse with Xtandi. So, uh, in my choosing those two, I have been choosing Zytiga, just for that reason. Uh, but the Xtandi is a little bit easier, because you just have to take Xtandi. You don’t have to take another drug. Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium.

When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
